Yellow Fever
FROM GEN. J. R. KEAN
FROM GEN, J. R. KEAN
1901
September 3, 1901.
THE NEW YORK TIMES. TUESDAY.
div1.p:
Official conservatism is very clearly
illustrated in the fact that the important
and apparently conclusive experiments
made in Cuba under the direction of
Surgeon REED, United States Army, re-
garding the conveyance and propagation
of yellow fever have thus far made little
or no impression upon the conventional
methods of quarantine. When it is re-
membered that any interruption of com -
merce imposes burdens upon merchants
and carriers which ultimately fall upon
the consumer, and are compensated in
increased prices and higher freight rates,
it becomes very clear that if the deten-
tion of ships from infected ports is as
unnecessary as the Cuban experiments
would warrant us in believing, the prac-
tice should be discontinued at every port
where quarantine has any other pur-
pose than to accumulate charges im-
posed and collected for the advantage of
the officials who assess and collect them,
as the robber barons once levied tolls
and duties on the commerce of the Rhine.

While it is doubtless true that the
Cuban tests have left some points in-
volved in doubt, the one question which
they appear to have settled beyond dis-
pute is that under no conditions which
admit of artificial production is it possi-
ble to infect the non-immune from con-
tact with the fomites of yellow fever in
clothing, bedding, and personal effects.
Even rags for paper stock could not very
well be as dangerous as the fabrics from
the beds of patients who had died from
yellow fever in Las Animas Hospital,
in which non-immunes slept for weeks
under the conditions of high tempera-
ture, artificial dampness, and so little
ventilation as to threaten asphyxiation.
Disinfection becomes as ineffective as an
incantation when there is nothing in
the way of infectious germs to destroy.
In the case of a house in which yellow
fever has occurred the question with the
United States Army experts in Cuba is
simply how to destroy the mosquitos
which may have bitten the patients.
Sulphur fumes and formaldehyde are the
favorite agencies for the destruction of
the culex; but, their destruction accom-
plished, further disinfection would seem
to be a waste of time and material.
Either will kill all the mosquitos in from
ten to different minutes, and as they are
as dead at the end of that time as they
ever will be, this period would seem to
fix the limit of useful quarantine deten-
tion. In his report on sanitation and
yellow fever in Havana. Surgeon HAV-
ARD, United States Army, after describ-
ing the very simple process of house dis-
infection now practiced, says: “The
duties of quarantine officers have also
become singularly simplified. Since we
may assume in practice that the infec-
tious germs do not exist outside of man
or mosquito, the disinfection of trunks
and baggage on account of yellow fever
is no longer justifiable. All that is re-
quired will be the examination of the
non-immunes within the five days imme-
diately following their last exposure to
infection, the danger of transmission be-
ing from their own persons, and in no-
wise from their clothing or baggage.
Ships, like houses, are liable to harbor
infected mosquitos, and will continue to
require fumigation.”

It is not a sufficient answer to the
concurrent judgement of our army Sur-
geons to brush their conclusions aside as
“not proven.” The results they have
attained have carried their work far
beyond the theoretical stage, and better
proof than they have given of the abso-
lute correctness of their observations
could not be furnished outside of a math-
ematical demonstration. The Province
of Santiago is now as free from yellow
fever as New York. This result in what
for more than four centuries has been
the home of yellow fever and a centre
of infection is as good proof as even the
most conservative practitioner of medical
traditions should need to satisfy him
that new truths have been added to the
sum of human knowledge of the etiology
of this dread disease. The results in
Havana are not yet quite as complete
as they are in Santiago, but are suffi-
ciently remarkable to leave no room for
doubt that the progress has been along
lines which will lead to the complete
extinction of the disease.

Of the work in Havana, the report on
this subject lately published by the War
Department, through the Division of In-
sular Affairs, says:

There have been years in which there
was very little yellow fever, but none in
which it has entirely disappeared as at
present. It would therefore seem to be a
fair inference that the improved method of
disinfection killed off the infected mosqui-
tos; that by March 8 the city had been rid
of the infection, and was free of fever un-
til April 20, when a focus of infection
again developed. Disinfection again ap-
parently killed the infected mosquitos, as
the city was free from fever until May 6,
when another focus developed. The same
method of disinfection was again applied,
with the result that no cases developed
after that date. It is believed that, pursu-
ing the present methods, the island can be
rid of yellow fever, and its spread may be
prevented even when introduced from the
outside. If this condition can be brought
about many of the restrictions now imposed
upon commerce by quarantines can be done
away with.

It is encouraging that, in accordance
with the suggestion made at and ap-
proved by the third Pan_American Med-
ical Congress in Havana, a conference
has been called of delegates represent-
ing the several American republics, to
consider and, if possible, agree upon a
uniform system of quarantine in accord-
ance with what the work of the past two
years has demonstrated in Cuba. It
should be remembered, however, that
traditions die hard and that ancient
superstitions have surprising vitality.
